biography.content: Dr. Aitchison is a Professor in the Department of Psychiatry and an Adjunct Professor in the Department of Medical Genetics at the University of Alberta, and the Lead Psychiatrist for the Edmonton Early Psychosis Intervention Clinic.  She obtained her BA(Hons, First Class, in Physiological Sciences, with a University Prize) and BM BCh (MD equivalent) from the University of Oxford, psychiatry specialist training (MRCPsych) from the Maudsley Hospital, and PhD (Wellcome Trust funded) in pharmacogenetics from King’s College London.  The latter included a Travelling Fellowship to the National Institutes of Health and the University of Colorado (USA). Her Chair program of work (2011-2016) was in Mental Illness and Addictions (http://www.albertahealthservices.ca/research/Page11182.aspx). Her publication areas include pharmacogenomics, human genetics, psychopharmacology, and mental health outcomes.  She coauthored a book entitled “First Episode Psychosis” that has been used worldwide and translated into Korean. Dr Aitchison served on the Faculty of King’s College London from 2001-2011, and joined the Faculty of the University of Alberta in September 2011. She co-led a successfully completed multicentre international pharmacogenomics study (GENDEP) from 2004 to 2008 (European Commission funded), and has served on Committees including the Consensus Statement on Improving Mental Health Transitions (Jury; http://www.ihe.ca/advanced-search/consensus-statement-on-improving-mental-health-transitions), Canadian Scientific Advisory Committee on Substance Abuse, and serves on others including the Alberta Psychiatric Association Executive Committee and the Alberta Psychiatric Association Annual Scientific Conference Committee (Scientific Program Co-Chair), Psychiatry Resident Research Committee (Chair, and Director, Resident Research, University of Alberta). Recognitions and awards include: Junior Investigator Award, International Society of Psychiatric Genetics (1995), Wellcome Mental Health Research Training Fellowship (1996), Young Investigator Award, International Congress in Schizophrenia Research (1997), Lilly Travelling Fellowship, Royal College of Psychiatrists (1997), Young Scientist Award, 10th Biennial Winter Workshop on Schizophrenia (2000), Local Clinical Excellence Award Level 4, South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust (2007, having been awarded Local Clinical Excellence Awards an increasing levels on an approximately annual basis in prior years), Fellowship of the Royal College of Psychiatrists, UK (2012, awarded as a mark of distinction and recognition of contributions to psychiatry), Invited by the Indocanadian Psychiatric Association to give a presentation at their Annual Meeting as a Distinguished Speaker (2015), and recent election to Membership of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology.
